Description: Houston-based CCS (USA) Inc. and several of its operating subsidiaries will pay a $2.5 million civil penalty relating to operations at its Shreveport, Louisiana, industrial wastewater treatment plant, the Department of Justice, U.S. Environmental Protection Agency and the state of Louisiana announced. The settlement will resolve violations of the Clean Water Act, the Clean Air Act and the hazardous waste law known as RCRA.
Agency: Environmental Protection Agency referral to the Justice Department
Info Source: http://www.justice.gov/opa/pr/us-branch-canadian-company-pay-25-million-penalty-shreveport-la-wastewater-plant

Description: The United States Attorney's Office for the Eastern District of California and the U.S. Environmental Protection Agency (EPA) announced that Forward Inc., of Manteca, agreed to a settlement to resolve alleged violations of air pollution laws at its landfill in Manteca. The settlement required Forward to spend approximately $3.8 million to improve the landfills gas collection and control system and to replace trucks in the landfills fleet with less polluting vehicles. Forward also agreed to pay a civil penalty of $200,000, to be shared with the San Joaquin Valley Unified Air Pollution Control District, a co-plaintiff in the enforcement action against Forward.
Info Source: https://archive.epa.gov/epapages/newsroom_archive/newsreleases/baf2458a998ce62e852579cf005ffef4.html

Description: Allied Waste agreed to pay more than $464,000 in unpaid wages, in settlement of allegations it failed to pay prevailing wages in publicly funded trash hauling services.
Info Source: https://web.archive.org/web/20011217151623/http://www.ago.state.ma.us/allwaste.asp

Company: Allied Waste Services of Massachusetts, LLC
Description: Allied Waste agreed to pay $1.327 million in restitution in settlement of allegations it failed to pay the prevailing wage for trash disposal work. This payment was the result of a previous settlement over prevailing wage and overtime violations in March 2009 that included a supplemental audit which discovered these new violations.
Info Source: https://web.archive.org/web/20100529211750/http://www.mass.gov/?pageID=cagopressrelease&L=1&L0=Home&sid=Cago&b=pressrelease&f=2010_04_29_allied_waste_agreement&csid=Cago

Company: Allied Waste Services of Massachusetts, LLC
Description: In March 2009 Allied Waste agreed to pay $454,000 in restitution and penalties in settlement of allegations it failed to pay the prevailing wage or overtime required for public trash disposal work. As part of the settlement the company cooperated with a supplemental audit of the wage and overtime calculations for all employees in the Commonwealth, leading to a later settlement.
Info Source: https://web.archive.org/web/20100529211750/http://www.mass.gov/?pageID=cagopressrelease&L=1&L0=Home&sid=Cago&b=pressrelease&f=2010_04_29_allied_waste_agreement&csid=Cago

Company: Allied Waste Services of North America, LLC
Info Source: Attorney General Schneiderman Announces Settlement With Allied Waste Services for Failure to Pay Buffalo Workers Legal Living Wage, Targeted News Service, September 27, 2017 (via Nexis).

Company: BFI Waste Systems of North America, Inc.
Info Source: https://web.archive.org/web/20120416180312/http://attorneygeneral.utah.gov/620.html

Company: Browning Ferris Industries of Ohio, Inc.
Info Source: State of Ohio Reaches Agreement for Violations at Mahoming County Landfill; Operator to Make Improvements, Pay $261,000 Civil Penalty, US States News, January 7, 2005 (via Nexis).

Description: D & L Disposal agreed to pay $8,500 civil penalty and provide $45,500 worth of landfill capacity at its facilities in settlement of allegations it improperly stored and disposed of hazardous waste when a small glass vial of mercury left in its Greenville office broke.
Info Source: https://web.archive.org/web/20090622015631/http://www.illinoisattorneygeneral.gov/pressroom/2008_10/20081028.html

Description: Republic Services agreed to reimburse the state up to $1.49 million in costs for oversight of the Bridgeton Landfill, monitoring an underground fire and making efforts to prevent it from reaching radioactive material in an adjacent landfill as well as installing systems to deal with the hazardous gases the fire produced. The state retained the right to seek recovery of more costs.
Info Source: https://web.archive.org/web/20150910053607/http://ago.mo.gov/home/news-archives/2014-news-archives/ag-koster-reaches-agreement-with-republic-services-on-additional-fire-and-odor-control-measures-at-the-bridgeton-landfill

Description: air pollution and solid waste violations
Info Source: https://web.archive.org/web/20141102071427/http://www.doj.state.wi.us/media-center/2010-news-releases/november-10-2010
https://web.archive.org/web/20070831215425/http://www.doj.state.wi.us/news/2004/nr121604_ENV.asp

Description: Bridgeton Landfill, LLC, Allied Services, LLC, and Republic Services, Inc. agreed to settle allegations they violated Missouri's environmental regulations and related claims over the subsurface fire at the Bridgeton Landfill. Republic Services, Inc. secured a $26 million bond and paid $61 million in additional funding for its mitigation activities, Bridgeton Landfill, LLC set up a $12.5 million fund for restitution and paid $3.5 million in penalties and damages.
Info Source: https://web.archive.org/web/20181228152957/http://ago.mo.gov/home/news-archives/2018-news-archives/ag-hawley-announces-settlement-agreement-reached-in-bridgeton-landfill-lawsuit
